_meanings:
{@--1@} The 
Supreme Being, regarded as impersonal
and divested of all quality and 
action; (according to the Vedāntins,
Brahman is both the efficient and
the material cause of the visible
universe, the all-pervading soul and
spirit of the universe, the essence
from which all created things are
produced and into which they are
absorbed; {#asti#} 
{#tAvannityaSadDabudDamuktasvaBAvaM sarvajYaM sarvaSaktisamanvitaM brahma#} <ls>Ś. B.</ls>);
{#samIBUtA dfzwistriBuvanamapi brahma manute#} <ls>Bh.</ls>;
<ls>Bh. 3. 84</ls>; <ls>Ku. 3. 15.</ls>

{@--12@} The Brāhmaṇa
portion of the Veda.

{@--1@} The Supreme Being,
the Creator, the first deity of the 
sacred Hindu Trinity, to whom is 
entrusted the work of creating the world
[The accounts of the creation of the
world differ in many respects; but, 
according to Manu Smṛti, the universe
was enveloped in darkness, and the 
selfexistent Lord manifested himself 
dispelling the gloom. He first created the
waters and deposited in them a seed.
This seed became a golden egg, in which
he himself was born as Brahmā--the
progenitor of all the worlds. Then the
Lord divided the egg into two parts,
with which he constructed heaven and
earth. He then created the ten 
Prajāpatis or mind-born sons who 
completed the work of creation. According to
another account (Rāmāyaṇa) Brahmā
sprang from ether; from him was 
descended Marīci, and his son was 
Kaśyapa. From Kaśyapa sprang Vivasvat,
and Manu sprang from him. Thus
Manu was the procreator of all human
beings. According to a third account,
the Supreme deity, after dividing the
golden egg, separated himself into two
parts, male and female, from which
sprang Virāj and from him Manu; <ab>cf.</ab> 

<ls>Ku. 2. 7</ls> and <ls>Ms. 1. 32</ls> {%et seq.%}. 
Mythologically Brahman is represented as 
being born in a lotus which sprang from
the navel of Viṣṇu, and as creating the
world by an illicit connection with his
own daughter Sarasvatī. Brahman had
originally five heads, but one of them was
cut down by Śiva with the ring-finger
or burnt down by the fire from his third
eye. His vehicle is a swan. He has
numerous epithets, most of which have
reference to his birth in a lotus].

{@--4@} One of the four
R{%itvijas%} or priests employed at a
Soma sacrifice.

{@--8@} An epithet of the
seven Prajāpatis:-- {#marIci, atri#}, 
{#aMgiras, pulasya, pulaha, kratu#} and {#vasizWa#}.

{2} one who
has touched the several parts of his
body by the repetition of 
Mantras; <ls>Ku. 3. 15</ls> (see <ls>Malli.</ls>
thereon).

{1} respectful 
salutation with folded hands while 
repeating the Veda.

{2} obeisance to
a preceptor (at the beginning and
conclusion of the repetition of the
Veda).

‘the egg of Brahman’, the
primordial egg from which the 
universe sprang, the world, universe;
{#brahmAMqacCatradaMqaH#} <ls>Dk. 1.</ls>

<ab>N.</ab> of one
of the eighteen Purāṇas.

an epithet of the river 
Godāvarī.

{2} devoting oneself to the Supreme
Spirit.

{4} a mode
of performing the Śrāddha in which
no Piṇḍas or rice-balls are offered.

a missile presided over by
Brahman.

<ab>N.</ab> of
the tract between the rivers 
Sarasvatī and Dṛṣadvatī (north-west
of Hastināpura);  
{#sarasvatIdfzadvatyordevanadyoryadaMtaraM . taM devanirmitaM deSaM brahmAvartaM#}
{#pracakzate#} <ls>Ms. 2. 17</ls>, <ls n="Ms. 2.">19</ls>; <ls>Me. 48.</ls>

a particular position for profound 

meditation.

forgetting or neglecting the Vedas;  
<ls>Ms. 11. 57</ls> ({#aDItavedasyAnaByAsena vismaraRaM#} <ls>Kull.</ls>).

explaining the
Veda, treatment or discussion of
theological problems.

instruction in the Vedas or sacred
knowledge.

<ab>N.</ab> of a 
district; ({#kurukzetraM ca matsyASca paMcAlAH#} 
{#SUrasenakAH . eza brahmarzideSo vE brahmAvartAdanaMtaraH#}  
<ls>Ms. 2. 19</ls>).

food given to
the priests at a sacrifice.

a
tax paid to the priestly class.

{1} the religious duties of a
Brāhmaṇa.

{2} the office of 
Brahman, one of the four principal priests
at a sacrifice.

an epithet
of Dākṣāyaṇī (who dwells in the
heart of men).

the portion of the
Veda relating to spiritual 
knowledge.

the treasure
of the Vedas, the entire 
collection of the Vedas; {#kzAtro DarmaH Srita#}
{#iva tanuM brahmakoSasya guptyE#} <ls>U. 6. 9.</ls>

<ab>N.</ab> of an astronomer born in
598 <ab>A. D.</ab>

respect for the missile 
presided over by Brahman; <ls>Bk. 9. 76</ls>
({#mA BUnmoGo brAhmaH pASa iti#}).
<ab>N.</ab> of a particular joint of the body.

a kind of ghost, the
ghost of a Brāhmaṇa, who 
during his life time indulges in a
disdainful spirit and carries away
the wives of others and the property
of Brāhmaṇas; ({#parasya yozitaM hftvA#} 
{#brahmasvamapahftya ca . araRye nirjale deSe Bavati#}
{#brahmarAkzasaH ..#} <ls>Y. 3. 212</ls>; <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Ms. 12. 60</ls>
also).

a woman on the second day of her
courses.

{2} the sacred word, the Vedas 

collectively; <ls>U. 6. 9.</ls> v. 1

the life
of a religious student.

a 
religious student, a Brāhmaṇa in the
first order of his life, who continues
to live with his spiritual guide
from the investiture with sacred
thread and performs the duties 
pertaining to his order till he settles
in life; <ls>Ms. 2. 41</ls>, <ls n="Ms. 2.">175</ls>; <ls n="Ms.">6. 87.</ls>

{2} a woman who observes
the vow of chastity.

the paramour of a
Brāhmaṇa's wife.

a 
mercenary Brāhmaṇa (who converts
his sacred knowledge into trade).
a Brāhmaṇa who lives by sacred
knowledge.

true or divine knowledge,
knowledge of the identity of the
universe with Brahma.

{1} the light of Brahma or the
Supreme Being.

the true knowledge of
the Supreme Spirit.

{2} Brāhmaṇic
lustre, the lustre or glory supposed
to surround a Brāhmaṇa.

{2} a tribute
paid to a Brāhmaṇa.

{2} sacred
knowledge, received as an 
inheritance or hereditary gift.

{1} instruction in the Vedas, the 
imparting of sacred knowledge.

{3} the earthly possession
of a Brāhmaṇa

{1} one who
receives the Vedas as his hereditary
gift, a Brāhmaṇa.

married according to the Brāhma
form of marriage.

a 
Brāhmaṇa changed into a demon; <ab>cf.</ab>  
{#brahmagraha#}.

{2} hostile to religious acts
or devotion, impious, godless.
an epithet of the river Sarasvatī.

absorbed in or intent on the
contemplation of the Supreme 
Spirit.

{1} the rank or position of a 
Brāhmaṇa.

{2} the place of the Supreme 
Spirit.

a complete study of the Vedas, the
entire Veda; <ls>U. 4. 9</ls>; <ls>Mv. 1. 14.</ls>

<ab>N.</ab> of a missile presided over
by Brahman; <ls>Bk. 9. 75.</ls>

{2} <ab>N.</ab> of a (male)
river which rises in the eastern 
extremity of the Himālaya and falls
with the Ganges into the Bay of
Bengal.

an epithet of the river
Sarasvatī.

<ab>N.</ab>
of one of the eighteen Purāṇas.

a minister of Brahman (the five
vital airs).

the universal 
destruction at the end of one hundred
years of Brahman in which even
the Supreme Being is supposed to
be swallowed up.

{1} a contemptuous term for
a Brāhmaṇa, an unworthy 
Brāhmaṇa (<ab>cf.</ab> <ab>Mar.</ab> {#mawurgA#});  
<ls>M. 4</ls>; <ls>V. 2.</ls>

{2} one who is a 
Brāhmaṇa only by caste, a nominal
Brāhmaṇa.

one who pretends to
be a Brāhmaṇa.

{2} the share of the chief 

priest.

become one with Brahma, 
absorbed into the Supreme Spirit.

{2} Brāhmaṇahood, the state
or rank of a Brāhmaṇa.
a festival in honor of Brāhmaṇas.

the Vedānta 
philosophy which inquires into the
nature of Brahma or Supreme
Spirit.

cultivation or
acquisition of spiritual knowledge.

{2} the author of the Vedas or of
Brahman; <ls>Ku. 6. 18.</ls>

{%<ab>a.</ab>%} intent
on the means of attaining sacred
knowledge; <ls>Ms. 10. 74.</ls>

a 
valuable present made to a Brāhmaṇa

an aperture in the crown of the head
through which the soul is said to
escape on its leaving the body.

{1} the whole mass or
circle of sacred knowledge.

lines written by the creator on
the forehead of a man which 
indicate his destiny, the predestined
lot of any man.

{2} the inherent
sanctity or power of a Brāhmaṇa; <ls>Ś. 6.</ls>

holy or 
sanctified by spiritual pre-eminence, holy.

{2} a follower of the Vedānta 
philosophy.

a drop of saliva 
sputtered while reciting the Vedas.

<ab>N.</ab> of one
of the eighteen Purāṇas.

{2} a place for 
reciting the Vedas.

an epithet of the
river Sarasvatī.
the hall or court of Brahman.

{1} the sacred thread worn by the 

Brāhmaṇas or the twice-born over
the shoulder.

{2} the aphorisms of
the Vedānta philosophy by 
Bādarāyaṇa.

acquiring holy knowledge by unlawful
means.

the property or possessions of
a Brāhmaṇa; <ls>Y. 3. 212.</ls>

of the nature of the
Supreme Spirit.

one of the five daily Yajñas or
sacrifices, which consists in offering
the rites of hospitality to guests; <ab>cf.</ab>
<ls>Ms. 3. 74.</ls>
